<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 123, 645, 149]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 171, 195, 202]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 221, 170, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 214, 428, 258]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 722, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 214, 907, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 278, 235, 294]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 303, 243, 318]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 420, 225, 435]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 450, 761, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 466, 809, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 482, 566, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 497, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 512, 364, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 527, 870, 558]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 558, 485, 573]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 573, 883, 603]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 603, 858, 634]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 634, 784, 650]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 682, 217, 696]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 697, 386, 712]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 712, 732, 728]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
A car starts from rest and moves in a straight line with constant acceleration for a distance of \(200 \text{m}\), reaching a speed of \(25 \text{m s}^{-1}\). The car then travels at this speed for \(400 \text{m}\), before decelerating uniformly to rest over a period of \(5 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 135, 532, 154]]<|/det|>
Find the time for which the car is accelerating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 342, 148, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 342, 803, 361]]<|/det|>
Sketch the velocity–time graph for the motion of the car, showing the key points.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 342, 920, 361]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Two particles \(P\) and \(Q\), of masses \(0.5 \mathrm{kg}\) and \(0.3 \mathrm{kg}\) respectively, are connected by a light inextensible string. The string is taut and \(P\) is vertically above \(Q\). A force of magnitude \(10 \mathrm{N}\) is applied to \(P\) vertically upwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 776, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the acceleration of the particles and the tension in the string connecting them.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A crate of mass \(300\mathrm{kg}\) is at rest on rough horizontal ground. The coefficient of friction between the crate and the ground is 0.5. A force of magnitude \(X\mathrm{N}\), acting at an angle \(\alpha\) above the horizontal, is applied to the crate, where \(\sin \alpha = 0.28\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 623, 154]]<|/det|>
Find the greatest value of \(X\) for which the crate remains at rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 81, 715, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 394, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
Three coplanar forces of magnitudes \(20 \text{N}, 100 \text{N}\) and \(F \text{N}\) act at a point. The directions of these forces are shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 440, 593, 460]]<|/det|>
Given that the three forces are in equilibrium, find \(F\) and \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 441, 920, 459]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
Two racing cars \(A\) and \(B\) are at rest alongside each other at a point \(O\) on a straight horizontal test track. The mass of \(A\) is \(1200\mathrm{kg}\). The engine of \(A\) produces a constant driving force of \(4500\mathrm{N}\). When \(A\) arrives at a point \(P\) its speed is \(25\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\). The distance \(OP\) is \(d\mathrm{m}\). The work done against the resistance force experienced by \(A\) between \(O\) and \(P\) is \(75 000\mathrm{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 152, 146, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 152, 313, 170]]<|/det|>
Show that \(d = 100\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Car \(B\) starts off at the same instant as car \(A\). The two cars arrive at \(P\) simultaneously and with the same speed. The engine of \(B\) produces a driving force of \(3200\mathrm{N}\) and the car experiences a constant resistance to motion of \(1200\mathrm{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 148, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 316, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the mass of \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 170, 920, 186]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 542, 146, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 542, 920, 574]]<|/det|>
Find the steady speed which \(B\) can maintain when its engine is working at the same rate as it is at \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 555, 920, 574]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 592, 920, 608]]<|/det|>

<form>......

<form>......

<form>......

<form>......

<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 944, 175, 958]]<|/det|>
<label>©</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
A particle starts from a point \(O\) and moves in a straight line. The velocity \(\nu \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) of the particle at time \(t \mathrm{s}\) after leaving \(O\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 109, 564, 129]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = k(3t^{2} - 2t^{3}),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 134, 292, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 166, 146, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 165, 536, 184]]<|/det|>
Verify that the particle returns to \(O\) when \(t = 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 166, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
It is given that the acceleration of the particle is \(-13.5 \mathrm{m s}^{-2}\) for the positive value of \(t\) at which \(\nu = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 821, 138]]<|/det|>
Find \(k\) and hence find the total distance travelled in the first two seconds of motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
Two particles \(A\) and \(B\), of masses \(0.4 \text{kg}\) and \(0.2 \text{kg}\) respectively, are moving down the same line of greatest slope of a smooth plane. The plane is inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal, and \(A\) is higher up the plane than \(B\). When the particles collide, the speeds of \(A\) and \(B\) are \(3 \text{m s}^{-1}\) and \(2 \text{m s}^{-1}\) respectively. In the collision between the particles, the speed of \(A\) is reduced to \(2.5 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 152, 146, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 152, 568, 170]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of \(B\) immediately after the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 918, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 428, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
After the collision, when \(B\) has moved \(1.6 \text{m}\) down the plane from the point of collision, it hits a barrier and returns back up the same line of greatest slope. \(B\) hits the barrier \(0.4 \text{s}\) after the collision, and when it hits the barrier, its speed is reduced by \(90\%\). The two particles collide again \(0.44 \text{s}\) after their previous collision, and they then coalesce on impact.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 507, 146, 525]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 507, 920, 540]]<|/det|>
Show that the speed of \(B\) immediately after it hits the barrier is \(0.5 \text{m s}^{-1}\). Hence find the speed of the combined particle immediately after the second collision between \(A\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 521, 920, 540]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 74, 569, 92]]<|/det|>
## Additional Page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 104, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
If you use the following lined page to complete the answer(s) to any question(s), the question number(s) must be clearly shown.
